The speed of sound in air at 20° Celsius (68° Fahrenheit) is approximately 343 meters per second, or about 767 miles per hour. However, the speed of sound can vary depending on the temperature, humidity, and density of the medium it is passing through.

The speed of light, on the other hand, is a constant and does not depend on the medium it is passing through. The speed of light in a vacuum is approximately 299,792 kilometers per second, or about 186,282 miles per second. This is equivalent to approximately 670,616,629 miles per hour, or about 1.08 billion kilometers per hour.

It's worth noting that the speed of light is the fastest speed at which information can travel, and it is one of the fundamental constants of the universe.

The speed of sound in air at 20°C (68°F) is approximately 343 meters per second (1,125 feet per second or 767 miles per hour). This value can vary depending on factors such as temperature, humidity, and altitude.

The speed of light, on the other hand, is a much higher value and is considered a universal constant. It's important to note that the speed of sound is significantly slower than the speed of light, which is why we see lightning before we hear thunder during a storm. The difference in speed allows the light from the lightning to reach our eyes before the sound of the thunder can reach our ears.
